title: Sources
text: The data used to create this project came from Kaggle. The tidyverse, broom, easystats libraries and AI (chatgpt & claude) were used in this project to make the graphs, models, etc. All of the 10,000 rows of data were taken into consideration in this project.

title: Flight Price Prediction
text: The bar chart displays the average flight prices by airline, along with error bars indicating price variability. Jet Airways, Multiple carriers Premium economy, and Air India show the highest average prices among all airlines. In contrast, Trujet, SpiceJet, and Air Asia offer the lowest average fares. Notably, Vistara Premium economy has a high variability in pricing, suggesting inconsistency or limited sample size.

title: Flight Price Prediction
section: Average Flight Price by Number of Stops
text:
Average Flight Price by Number of Stops

















Summary Statistics by Total Stops:


# A tibble: 4 × 7
  Total_Stops count mean_price median_price sd_price min_price max_price
  <chr>       <int>      <dbl>        <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
1 3 stops        45     13112        12954     2963.      8607     21829
2 2 stops      1518     12667.       12756.    3111.      4647     34608
3 1 stop       5621     10557.       10262     4041.      3480     54826
4 non-stop     3491      5025.        4667     2078.      1759     31945



Correlation between number of stops and price: 0.621


Flight prices tend to increase with the number of stops. Non-stop flights are the cheapest on average, with a mean price of $5,025, while flights with 3 stops are the most expensive, averaging $13,112. The correlation coefficient of 0.621 indicates a moderately strong positive relationship between the number of stops and ticket price. This suggests that more stops generally lead to higher fares.

title: Model
text:
Linear Regession Model Equation
\[
\begin{aligned}
\hat{Y} =\ & 7753 \\
& + 1846 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Air India}} \\
& -\ 37 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{GoAir}} \\
& + 267 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{IndiGo}} \\
& + 4158 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Jet Airways}} \\
& + 3050 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Multiple carriers}} \\
& + 3661 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Multiple carriers Premium economy}} \\
& -\ 208 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{SpiceJet}} \\
& -\ 3615 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Trujet}} \\
& + 2197 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Vistara}} \\
& + 5124 \cdot \text{Airline}_{\text{Vistara Premium economy}} \\
& + 2002 \cdot \text{Stops}_{\text{2 stops}} \\
& + 3286 \cdot \text{Stops}_{\text{3 stops}} \\
& + 8073 \cdot \text{Stops}_{\text{4 stops}} \\
& -\ 3917 \cdot \text{Stops}_{\text{non-stop}} \\
& + 0.495 \cdot \text{duration\_total\_hr}
\end{aligned}
\]









The plot illustrates the predicted ticket prices across different airlines based on a linear regression model that incorporates Airline, Total Stops, and Total Duration (hours) as predictors. Each line represents a specific airline, showing how price varies across the observed range of values. Airlines such as Jet Airways, Air India, and Multiple Carriers display wider price ranges and more variability, while budget airlines like GoAir and SpiceJet show tighter, more consistent pricing patterns. The dense overlap of lines in the lower price range (below 20,000) suggests that many airlines operate within similar pricing bands, though premium carriers and classes (e.g., Vistara Premium Economy) occupy higher price segments. This model-based visualization helps identify airline-specific pricing trends and supports comparison across carrier types.
